captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]
[CAR ENGINE]
LARRY KOSILLA: Hey, guys.

I bought the car, and
I'm so stoked.

The pre-purchase inspection we
did last episode totally

helped me negotiate a fair
price for the car.

As expected, there are few
things on the 964 that need a
little love--

some engine work, dent removal,
touch-ups, tinting,
and, of course, wheel repair.

Now, the wheels on the 964
are in pretty bad shape.

And I'm considering my options
for getting them fixed.

So on today's episode, we're at
Performance Industries in
New Rochelle, New York.

We're going to show you the
behind-the-scenes look at how

one of the best shops in the
world professionally repairs
scuffed and bent rims.

That's all coming up today on
this episode of /DRIVE CLEAN.
[ROCK MUSIC PLAYING]

Inside this unmarked shop lies
a maze of machines and

workstations designed to
diagnose, repair, rebuild,

clean, paint, and even fabricate
custom wheels.

Working as a detailer in New
York, it's common to see rims
damaged from city streets.

And this kills the overall
aesthetics of a car.

Simply replacing your rims
is not the only option.

George, the founder of
Performance Industries, is

going to walk us through the
five steps he performs when

addressing a wide variety of
rim issues, including bent,

scratched, and even cracked
wheels, as well as simply

updating the color and texture
of your current rims to change

the overall look and
feel of your car.

LARRY KOSILLA: Hey,
what's going on?
GEORGE GJOKAJ: Hi, what's up?

LARRY KOSILLA: Good
to see you, man.

GEORGE GJOKAJ: Nice
to see you too.

LARRY KOSILLA: What are
you doing here?

GEORGE GJOKAJ: Well, this is the
first stage of our wheel
repair process.

This is just a visual inspection
where we'll put it

on a spindle here, spin it,
and just take close

observation of any damage
you may have.

If we see any hop in it, we'll
mark it that it's bent.

If we see any gouges, we'll
mark it that it
needs a little welding.

And I'll take you through the
rest of the process now.
LARRY KOSILLA: OK.

All right, so what are we
doing with this machine?

GEORGE GJOKAJ: Well, this
machine is going to straighten
this bent wheel.

And in simple terms, we have
a dial indicator--
it's a measuring device.

This is mounted on a spindle,
and this wheel is perfectly
centered on this spindle.

So this dial indicator is
going to tell us how
bent this wheel is.

LARRY KOSILLA: Now, when
I touched this,
it was really warm.
Why is it so warm?

GEORGE GJOKAJ: Well, first,
we'll take the chill out of

the wheel, we'll heat
it with the torch.

Take the chill out of the
wheel, and I'll keep

manipulating and pressing on the
low spots, maybe bringing

down these couple high spots
here and reshaping this wheel.

Bringing it to within
factory specs.

Doing this all while not
compromising the structural
integrity of the wheel.

So Larry, once we straighten the
wheel, we bring them over
here and we strip them.

We developed this system,
because when we first started

out in this business, we
literally used to sandblast
the old finish.

We'd sit there for an
hour and a half
sandblasting this wheel.

Well, I developed this system
where we load eight wheels at

a time on these racks, and drop
them into the strip tank.

And there's a stripping
solution that's
environmentally friendly.

And within an hour, eight wheels
are stripped of their

old finish and ready for
a fresh powder coat.

All right, now we're in the
powder-coating room.

And you see, this is
a finished product.

But as you can see, we
hang them like so
from the valve stem.

We mask off the lug bolts, so
we can get proper torque

specs, so there's no
powder coat build
up for the lug bolts.

The mounting pad also
gets masked off.

This way, there's metal-to-metal
contact, so you

don't have any powder buildup
that can throw off the balance

of the wheel and
the hub board.

If you've ever changed a tire
and had to hit it with a

sledgehammer to get it off the
car, it was probably because

this surface wasn't masked
off, and the
fitment was too tight.

So you can see how thorough
this process is.

But once it's done, it's
virtually a new wheel.

You can't tell the difference
from a new wheel

out-of-the-box or
this finished.

LARRY KOSILLA: This looks
better than new.
This is perfect.

GEORGE GJOKAJ: But the part that
you don't see, Larry, is
this finish is super durable.

So when you're scraping at your
wheel, trying to get that

brake dust off, you're going
to appreciate this process.

So the final step is mounting
the tire and balancing it.

It's very important that you
fill these with, at minimum,
clean compressed air.

We ideally like to
put nitrogen.

Nitrogen maintains the air
pressure consistency over a

wider temperature range, which,
if you were to fill

this with a typical air
compressor, there's a lot of
moisture in that air.

So you get a lot of condensation
build-up on the

inside of the wheel, which
winter time could freeze,

could affect the life of the
tire and the performance of

the tire in that it won't
maintain the air pressure
consistency.

LARRY KOSILLA: And then you
Road Force balance them
afterwards?

GEORGE GJOKAJ: Yeah,
every wheel
gets Road Force balanced.

And the Road Force balance, a
roller, mimics the way it
drives on your car.

So it literally measures the
force that that tire is
pressing against the pavement.

Because if you don't
have that feature--

you can balance a square,
doesn't mean
it's going to drive--
LARRY KOSILLA: Got you.

GEORGE GJOKAJ: --nicely
on a car.

LARRY KOSILLA: All right, so
it's like you're in the car,
and it's pretending like--

GEORGE GJOKAJ: This system
assures that you'll have the

right ride quality,
balanced or not.

The Road Force is the key factor
in determining that

vibration in your
steering wheel.

LARRY KOSILLA: All right, So
I bought a new Porsche.
I'm really excited about it.
It's got the stock rims on it.

It has scratches, a
little bit's bent.
So what are my options?

GEORGE GJOKAJ: Let's go take
a look at it first.

LARRY KOSILLA: All right,
well here it is.
So what do think?

GEORGE GJOKAJ: You know Larry,
I don't really think it's

worth putting any money
into these 16s.

They've got some curb rash, and
the amount of time we'd

have to spend to refurbish them,
I don't think it's a
wise decision.

Let's pull this thing in and
put it on the lift, and
measure this up.

We want these crucial
measurements, from mounting

pad to the edge of the fender,
so these things fit beautiful.

LARRY KOSILLA: Now that the car
is pulled inside, we can

begin working on the crucial
measurements.

Be sure to place the car in
an area that is flat, and

properly lift and stabilize the
vehicle before taking any
measurements.

With the wheel removed, George
begins by measuring the size
of the disk brakes.

He continues by verifying the
backspacing in both the front
and rear parts of the hub.

Backspacing is a crucial part of
determining the appropriate

width and offset of your
future wheels.

We want to benefit from the
traction of a wider tire.

But at the same time, we also
want to avoid poking outside

the fender or getting in the
way of the wheel assembly
housed inside.

The overall vertical clearance
is important to note as well,

as it will factor into
your rim diameter.

Now, the previous owner most
likely installed a set of
wheels whose total diameter--

this includes the wheel and
tire-- that was too large,

which resulted in rub marks in
the upper part of the fender,
as you can see here.

GEORGE GJOKAJ: Taking everything
into consideration,

I think we need to sit down and
do the math, and figure

out what tire sizes are
available for this car.

Because the overall diameter
for the front and rear, we

want it to be constant with
the factory sizes.

And we want to figure out what
quality tire manufacturers

offer a matching set, front and
rear, in those tire sizes.

So we want, on a 265, I would
say, an eight and a half, nine
inch wheel.

It'll give you a nice square
profile on your tire.
It will look appropriate.

But we have room to put
that wide of a wheel.

We do not have that room to
put that wide of a tire.

So we want it to look
professional.

We want the side walls to sit
perpendicular to the floor.

We don't want them
at a 45-degree
degree angle being stretched.

Or too narrow of a tire, and a
wide tire bubbling over the
edge of the tire.

So we need to do this math,
figure out what tire sizes are

available, and then we'll
communicate some options here.

LARRY KOSILLA: Based on George's
recommendations, we

ran some sizing options
through the computer.

We further narrowed our list and
proceeded back to the car

to confirm and to double check
the final measurements,

including the bolt pattern
and the center board.

This is to ensure the
best possible fit.

GEORGE GJOKAJ: Four gauge,
telescoping board
gauge, fasten it.
Make sure in the right spot.

And then I hate to sound
obnoxious, but I don't care

what any book or manufacturer
tells me.

I have this measurement, and
this is what I'm going off of.

The overall diameter is
very, very close to
your factory specs.

You won't have any
clearance issues.

They are going to
fit beautiful.

You're going to have
less sidewall roll.

So this is a real great
plus-size option for you.

The only question now is,
according to those

measurements, do we go with a
boutique custom built wheel
that I make?

Or do we go with a reputable
aftermarket brand that can

meet these specs that
I measured?

When I do the math and figure
out the offset, is there a

brand out there that offers
that offset for this car?

And we need to research that
and weigh your options.

LARRY KOSILLA: George and the
guys over at Performance have

been amazing at helping me
figure out what my different
wheel options are.

Now, I've spent a little time
thinking about the style of

rim that would best
fit my 964.

And in the end, we decided on
the OEM Cup I wheels to keep
that Porsche feel.

But George and I wanted to make
the look a bit different

with a fresh bronze
powder coat.
And I couldn't be happier.

For a PDF of the top five
measurements needed to

determine the best wheel fitment
and to check out our

gallery of our favorite wheel
designs, visit ammonyc.com .
Well, that's it for me, guys.

Thanks, again, for watching
another episode of /DRIVE

CLEAN right here on the
/DRIVE network.

GEORGE GJOKAJ: This
is a true story.

The first set of wheels I did
for a Lamborghini Murcielago,

he said he wanted what
the industry standard
at that time was.

I said, we need to
do the math.
So I went back to do my math.

I said, I'm sorry, it's
not within 3% of
that overall diameter.

It's going to affect
your differentials.
And I almost lost the job.

Because how could all these
big companies be wrong?

I said, look, I did my math,
and I know what I'm

comfortable putting
on your car.
And this is all I'm comfortable
putting on your car.

Sure enough, he listened
to me.

And within four months, the
forums were flooded with guys

in their Murcielagos burning up
their differentials because
of the wrong tire sizes.
So this information is crucial.

title: Wheels & Rims: Repair, Refinish, and Fitment - /DRIVE CLEAN

comments.text: 5:34 dat bmw style 68 doe﻿
comments.author: Timothy Lambert

comments.text: Tldr; Buy factory rims.﻿
comments.author: Yanak Noah

comments.text:
Sure you can spend money and buy new or used wheels if you like. But it's 
not "not worth it" to spend the money to fix up your original wheels if 
they're something worthwhile (like those original 16in C4 wheels Larry had 
were). Could have actually been a very interesting video if only for the 
sake of education on the process of blasting the finish off the wheels and 
then repairing kerb rash. 

For you garage wrenchheads out there that want to fix some Kerbing and 
aren't afraid to get your hands dirty, check out spot putty. If it's a 
small bit of rash you can actually strip the paint of just that bit of 
wheel, apply the spot putty and hardening agent, sand to smooth and then 
repaint with the correct paint (on almost every german car it's Wurst 
Silver paint) take about an hour of your life but well worth it. 

If your wheel is rashed badly, just strip the entire wheel and use the spot 
putty and sandpaper to get the entire wheel nice and uniform. After that 
pick whatever paint + clear combo you want. Use a spray nozzle to keep your 
spray even sand it down between coats, especially fine sanding between 
clears.﻿

comments.text:
Larry, I love your videos and your knowledge you share is appreciated but 
please stop saying "rims", they are actually called "wheels", people that 
call them rims are generally not very knowledgable about cars and I know 
you are so please I'm begging you to call them "wheels", this is a pet 
peeve of mine that drives me nuts, technically a rim is actually only part 
of a wheel, a wheel is typically made of three components: a hub, spokes, 
and a rim! Thanks for what you do keep it up!﻿

comments.author: joeracer302

comments.text:
Nitrogen in road tyres is such a sham - clean dry air is 80% nitrogen 
anyway, and the claims made about the benefits of pure nitrogen are mostly 
bullshit - don't waste your money on nitrogen fills, just make sure your 
compressor is supplying dry air (and even that's not super important with 
modern tyres and wheels).﻿
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
+Matthew Sharpe This is like the Gluten Free debate. You can't convince the 
believers even with facts.
comments.author: Meh Ehm

comments.text:
Use your money on extra oil changes not on nitrogen for the tires your car 
will love you so much

comments.text:
+Matthew Sharpe gotta agree with you man, you have a very good point on 
this one. Nitrogen is only beneficial for race car tires that experience 
drastic heat cycles to keep them consistent. I tell ya, I sure wouldn't be 
able to tell the difference so I save my money...

comments.text:

deciding it was crap shows that I am no idiot - but think what you want.

Unless you have 500+ HP and track your car all the time you you might as

comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text: +Matthew Sharpe you are an idiot
comments.author: Neerav Reddy

comments.text: i get free nitrogen whenever i want at my local bmw dealer :)
comments.author: Neerav Reddy

comments.text:
You guys pay for nitrogen? Most of our tire shops fill them for free......I 
could take it or leave it on nitrogen on my primary tires, but I prefer 
nitrogen on my spares and storage tires/wheels. Nitrogen tends to reduce 
the amount of pressure loss over time, which is a good thing if you don't 
check your spare tire pressure that often.
comments.author: Kelvin Tso

comments.text:
The pure nitrogen for the average road car is a waste of money because the 
actual temperature change is minimal Pure nitrogen is used when a tyre will 
experience a lot of heat cycles as it is more stable than regular air and 
if it saves a 10th of a second a lap motorsport will jump on it for every 
day road use I wouldn't pay the extra for it only because i regularly 
adjust my tyre pressures and having to have a nitrogen supply in my garage 
to do that would be a nightmare.
comments.author: David Cooper

comments.text: +Matthew Sharpe Amen
comments.author: gerrar46

comments.text:
+Vort E It's true a lot of technology developed in racing does end up in 
passenger vehicles eventually - as OEM equipment, but a lot doesn't make it 
to passenger vehicles either - racing slicks for example - useful on the 
track - not so useful on the daily commute.

I've tried nitrogen (as it was offered free with a set of tyres) in my 
400rwhp road car which I occasionally take to track days - I could not tell 
the difference, my lap times did not change, the trip computer could not 
tell the difference - fuel economy & range remained identical, I still lost 
a couple of lb of pressure from the tyres a year like usual, and the tyres 
still wore out in the same way as the previous set.

So now I'm back to dry air from my compressor - and I still can't tell the 
difference.  If I wanted to fill with nitrogen I'd be looking at $20 + 
whatever they charge to top you up however often it needs it - for 
something I'm not going to notice at all even when driving much harder than 
I do on the road - why bother?

Add my personal experience to all the literature that says you can't tell 
or measure the difference in any meaningful way, plus my scientific 
knowledge - well I'm very satisfied that my opinion is not ignorant.

Maybe it's useful in a Nissan GTR, maybe a better driver would notice the 
difference - I don't know, my car is quick, but it's not anywhere near GTR 
quick, and I'm a very average enthusiast level driver.

Look, I've had this exact debate with my local tyre guy as he's convinced 
the product he is selling does his customers some good though he has 
nothing but personal anecdotes to back it up - but I honestly cannot tell 
the difference, and objective studies also say the same thing - so when 
people ask me about it, I tell them not to bother with it, it's a waste of 
money.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:

I've been in the industry for 15 years, Used nitrogen for the last 10 on 
all of my cars, Even my hilux with 300 000km, It's used in all forms of

know from my own experience, You think its a waste thats your opinion, But

End rant.

future? is wrapping bad for paint? how should i prep my car for wrapping?
